content:
<!-- Page 1 -->

DIAGNOSIS
∿

---

<!-- Page 2 -->



# NSCLC: Stage at Diagnosis

(SCLC)

*   Stage I: 10%
*   Stage II: 20%
*   Stage IIIA: 15%
*   Stage IIIB: 15%
*   Stage IV: 40%
    *   (NO Surgery)

Ettinger et al. Oncology. 1996; 10:81-111.

---

<!-- Page 3 -->



# 5 Year Survival Rates – By Stage

*   Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
    *   IA 58-73%
    *   IB 43-58%
    *   IIA 36-46%
    *   IIB 25-36%
    *   IIIA 19-24%
    *   IIIB 7-9%
    *   IV 2-13%
*   Small Cell Lung Cancer
    *   Limited 18-38%
    *   Extensive 1%

---

<!-- Page 4 -->



# Objectives of evaluation

The main objectives of the diagnostic evaluation and clinical staging are
* adequate tissue to establish the HPE diagnosis and,
* molecular characterization of the tumor,
* extent of disease

These goals should be accomplished in the safest, least invasive, and most cost-effective manner possible.

---

<!-- Page 5 -->

IMAGING EVALUATION

---

<!-- Page 6 -->



# Lung cancer : Investigations

*   I. CXR
*   CT CHEST (precise location)
*   CYTOLOGY (Sputum, Pleural fluid)
*   GOLD STD TEST: ? Biopsy
    *   HPE
    *   IHC
    *   Molecular testing (Driver mutations, PDL1 status)
*   MRI
*   PET
*   Bonescan

Dr. Bharath Katti MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 7 -->



# I. CHEST XRAY

? malignancy

1.  Solitary Pul nodule
2.  Mass [Spiculated]
3.  Collapse
4.  Plef
5.  mediastinal LN↑
6.  Pericardral effusion
7.  ↑ diaphragm elevation
8.  Rib #

Others :
-   Diffuse interstitial disease Lymphangitis carcinomatosis
-   Consolidation ✓
-   Cavity

---

<!-- Page 8 -->



## II. CT chest

CT - key features of the primary tumor (size, presence of satellite nodules, associated atelectasis, and invasion of adjacent structures);

Regional LN involvement can also be evaluated on chest CT. \* Staging

Lymph nodes are deemed to be pathologically enlarged when they measure greater than 1 cm in short-axis diameter on transverse images

The likelihood of metastatic involvement increases with the degree of lymph node enlargement: 62% of lymph nodes measuring 10 to 15 mm are malignant versus 90% of nodes measuring >15 mm.

In meta analysis About 20% of nodes deemed to be benign on chest CT were malignant
and 40% of nodes deemed abnormal on chest CT were benign

---

<!-- Page 9 -->

Chest CT can also demonstrate findings - metastatic disease.
CT helps to delineate pleural disease;
Bony involvement of the thoracic cage may be seen.
Adrenal lesions can be identified

---

<!-- Page 10 -->

IV contrast : CECT
1) differentiate the hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes from vascular structures
2) also helps to characterize hepatic and adrenal lesions.
3) neovascularity

---

<!-- Page 11 -->



### III Sputum cytology

Least invasive way of achieving a **histologic** diagnosis.

However, it is also the **least accurate** and least useful for therapeutic analysis. For these reasons, it has largely been replaced by other methods and is generally of **historic interest only**.

male patients predominating. Sensitivity of sputum cytology is 60%, and it increases with the number of samples examined. It is more for the central lesion compared with the peripheral lesion, and for squamous cell carcinoma compared with adenocarcinoma. Use of both sputum and BAL cytology increases the detection rate of lung cancer. Need for careful evaluation is patients with a sputum cytodiagnosis of

ORIGINAL ARTICLE
**Sputum cytology in suspected cases of carcinoma of lung (Sputum cytology a poor man's bronchoscopy!)**

Ammanagi, A. S.; Dombale, V. D.; Miskin, A. T.; Dandagi, G. L.; Sangolli, S. S.
Author Information

Lung India 29(1):p 19-23, Jan-Mar 2012. | DOI: 10.4103/0970-2113.92356

---

<!-- Page 12 -->



# Thoracentesis

Most effusions in _lung cancer_ are _malignant_.

Positive pleural fluid cytology establishes the diagnosis and also establishes stage IV disease.

Pleural fluid cytology sensitivity for malignancy overall is approximately 60% to 72% when a volume of at least 50 mL is sent; diagnostic yield does not appear to increase with larger volume of fluid analyzed.

If the initial thoracentesis is negative, a second thoracentesis should be performed, as it can increase the diagnostic yield by an additional 27%; additional samples add little to the diagnostic yield.

Sensitivity of pleural fluid cytology can be as high as 72% when at least two separate specimens are sent.

---

<!-- Page 13 -->

When pleural disease is present and thoracentesis is negative:
Closed pleural biopsy using an Abrams needle (7% to 27%).
\*image-guided pleural biopsy\*: with a sensitivity of 84%.
\*Thoracoscopy\* has a reported sensitivity of 80% to 99% in the diagnosis of malignant pleural disease.
when there is CT evidence of pleural thickening or nodules, the diagnostic yield of image-guided percutaneous biopsy is similar to thoracoscopy.

---

<!-- Page 14 -->

**PET-CT** : metastasis

FGD-PET PET-ve ❌ Not malignancy

more sensitive and specific than CT in regional lymph node assessment disclose unsuspected metastatic disease in 6% to 37% of cases.

Liver metastases, adrenal metastases, and bone metastases can be diagnosed with good accuracy.

---

<!-- Page 15 -->



# MRI

MRI scanning is the test of choice when assessing for intracranial metastatic disease.

MRI is also the test of choice for:
*   extent of chest wall invasion,
*   diaphragmatic involvement,
*   superior sulcus tumors,
*   brachial plexus invasion,
*   invasion of the spine (T4 disease).

---

<!-- Page 16 -->



# ESTABLISHING THE TISSUE DIAGNOSIS

*   ?? Biopsy
    *   CT guided
    *   Br. Biopsy
    *   Thoracoscopy
    *   SLB

---

<!-- Page 17 -->



# HISTOLOGIC SAMPLING OF THE PRIMARY TUMOR
Better Yield $\bar{c}$ central tumor.

| TUMOR CHARACTER                       | PROCEDURE                         | SENSITIVITY |
| :------------------------------------ | :-------------------------------- | :---------- |
| DIRECTLY VISUALIZED ENDOBRONCHIAL TUMOR Biopsy (drawing of bronchus with tumor) | BRONCHOSCOPY WITH FORCEPS BIOPSY | \* 75% \*   |
|                                       | BRONCHOSCOPIC WASH                | 47%         |
|                                       | ENDOBRONCHIAL BRUSH               | 61%         |

---

<!-- Page 18 -->

---

<!-- Page 19 -->

When all techniques are utilized, reported yield of
bronchoscopic sampling of endobronchial lesions can be
as high as 91% to 96%.
The utility of bronchoscopic sampling in patients with
peripheral primary tumor is much lower.

---

<!-- Page 20 -->

Trans bronchial needle biopsy

TTNB is recommended as the first line for biopsy of peripheral lung lesions in intermediate to high lung cancer likelihood patients when
(1) the lesion is peripheral;
(2) the lesion is less than 3 cm in size;vvvnnn
n (3) there is no CT/PET evidence of mediastinal lymph node or extrathoracic metastasis; and/or (4) the patient is a poor surgical candidate.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACR EDARM

---

<!-- Page 21 -->

# SLB Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (**VATS**) wedge resection followed by definitive anatomic resection (e.g., lobectomy) as indicated is the **gold standard** for **peripheral lung biopsy** with the **highest sensitivity and specificity**. (More risky) invasive In patients who have an acceptable surgical risk profile, a peripheral lesion **less than 3 cm**, and **no CT/PET evidence of metastatic disease** (lymph node or extrathoracic), **definitive VATS resection is preferred**, as it provides both **diagnosis and cure in one procedure**. Otherwise, despite overall lower yield, `bronchoscopic sampling` has become the preferred biopsy method in centers where `advanced bronchoscopy` technologies, including `R-EBUS` and `EMN`, are available --- # MEDIASTINAL STAGING * Nearly a quarter of patients with lung cancer have locally advanced disease with mediastinal involvement (N2 or N3) at the time of presentation. * Mediastinal staging is crucial in determining the stage of disease and candidacy for surgical resection once metastatic disease has been ruled out, as 29% to 66% of noncurative surgeries for lung cancer can be avoided with adequate mediastinal staging * Tissue confirmation of mediastinal nodal metastasis becomes unnecessary only in the following situations: (1) where distant metastatic disease has already been confirmed; (2) when the patient is not a candidate for any treatment; (3) in a peripheral lesion, less than 3 cm in size, with no radiographic evidence of lymph node metastasis DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM --- Patients with NSCLC -clinical staging of the mediastinum based on the radiographic findings | Group | Description | | :---- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | A | Mediastinal infiltration: tumor invasion such that normal anatomic boundaries cannot be distinguished | | B | Enlarged discrete mediastinal lymph nodes: lymph nodes measuring $\ge$1 cm in short-axis diameter on transverse CT scan | | C | Clinical stage II or central stage I tumor: normal-sized mediastinal lymph nodes but enlarged N1 nodes or central tumor | | D | Peripheral clinical stage I tumor: normal mediastinal and hilar nodes with a peripheral tumor | --- Dr. Sharath Katte Figure 112-2 Example of radiographic group A disease mediastinal infiltration with loss of normal anatomic boundaries. --- Figure 112-3 Example of radiographic Group B disease: discrete mediastinal (4R) nodal enlargement --- # Mediastinal staging Mediastinal staging procedures include * Transthoracic needle aspiration (TTNA), * Transbronchial needle aspiration (TBNA) with or without endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS), * Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) needle aspiration, * Cervical mediastinoscopy, * Anterior mediastinoscopy, * Thoracoscopy. Selection of *appropriate procedure* is made based upon *nodal station, pretest probability* of disease, and medical appropriateness for surgical resection. The diagnostic yield of *each procedure* should also be taken into account. --- # Regional lymph nodes ## Supraclavicular zone * 1 Low cervical, supraclavicular, and sternal notch nodes ## SUPERIOR MEDIASTINAL NODES ### Upper zone * 2R Upper Paratracheal (right) * 2L Upper Paratracheal (left) * 3a Prevascular * 3p Retrotracheal * 4R Lower Paratracheal (right) * 4L Lower Paratracheal (left) ## AORTIC NODES ### AP zone * 5 Subaortic * 6 Para-aortic (ascending aorta or phrenic) ## INFERIOR MEDIASTINAL NODES ### Subcarinal zone * 7 Subcarinal ### Lower zone * 8 Paraesophageal (below carina) * 9 Pulmonary ligament ## N1 NODES ### Hilar/Interlobar zone * 10 Hilar * 11 Interlobar ### Peripheral zone * 12 Lobar * 13 Segmental * 14 Subsegmental Adolfo San Juan, MD 2009 --- # Mediastinal Staging | Procedure | Lymph Node Stations | Sensitivity (%) | |---|---|---| | TBNA | 4, 7, and 10 | 78 | | EBUS-TBNA | 2, 4, 7, and 10 | 88–93 | | EUS-FNA | 5, 7–9 | 83, overall
90, enlarged nodes
58, normal-sized nodes | | CT-guided TTNA | 3a, 5, 6 | 92 | | Mediastinoscopy | 1, 2R, 2L, 3, 4R, 4L, anterior subcarinal (7) | 81 | | Thoracoscopy | 4, 7–10 | 99 | --- # TNM STAGING FOR LUNG CANCER {8TH EDITION} NSCLC *Annotations:* * **T**: Tumor * **N**: Node * **M**: Metastasis * SCLC (circled) --- T1 and T2 further divided into 1-cm increments. Central tumors involving a main bronchus are considered T2, regardless of distance from, but without involvement of, the main carina. Involvement of the diaphragm has been reclassified as T4. The classification of additional tumor nodules was maintained from the previous classification. The presence of a satellite nodule in the tumor-bearing lobe defines T3, whereas an additional nodule in a different lobe of the ipsilateral lung defines T4. The N category has remained unchanged in the last two iterations of the staging system and is determined by the location of the involved nodes (relative to the primary tumor). The M category has been further divided into M1a, b, and c, as prognosis was found to worsen increasingly from a to c. --- T1-T4 * **T1**: **Tumor ≤ 3 cm** surrounded by **visceral pleura** not involving main bronchus * T1a : <1 cm * T1b : 1-2cm * T1c : >2cm to ≤ 3 T2 : tumour **> 3 cm to 5 cm** or - any tumor that invades **visceral pleura** or main **bronchus** or **atelectasis up to hilum** ✓ T2a : >3cm to 4cm ✓ T2b : > 4cm to 5cm --- ## T3 Tumor >5 cm but ≤7 cm or Tumor that invades chest wall (including superior sulcus tumors), phrenic nerve, parietal pericardium; or satellite nodule(s) in the same lobe as the primary ## T4 * ESOPHAGUS * GREAT VESSELS * R/C LARYNGEAL NERVE * SPINE Tumor >7 cm or tumor that invades trachea, carina, diaphragm, mediastinum (heart, great vessels, recurrent laryngeal nerve, esophagus,) vertebral body, separate tumor nodule(s) in another lobe same side. --- Nodal Staging 14 **Supraclavicular zone** * 1 Low cervical, supraclavicular, and sternal notch nodes **SUPERIOR MEDIASTINAL NODES** **Upper zone** * 2R Upper Paratracheal (right) * 2L Upper Paratracheal (left) * 3a Prevascular * 3p Retrotracheal * 4R Lower Paratracheal (right) * 4L Lower Paratracheal (left) **AORTIC NODES** **AP zone** * 5 Subaortic * 6 Para-aortic (ascending aorta or phrenic) **INFERIOR MEDIASTINAL NODES** **Subcarinal zone** * 7 Subcarinal **Lower zone** * 8 Paraesophageal (below carina) * 9 Pulmonary ligament **N1 NODES** **Hilar/Interlobar zone** * 10 Hilar * 11 Interlobar **Peripheral zone** * 12 Lobar * 13 Segmental * 14 Subsegmental --- # NODES STAGING / SPREAD | A. | B. Superior mediastinal | C. Aortic | D. Inferior mediastinal | E. Hilar and intra pul nodes (N1) nodes | | :-- | :----------------------- | :-------- | :---------------------- | :--------------------------------------- | | 1. Supraclavicular | 2. Upper paratracheal | 5. Sub aortic | 7. Subcarinal | 10. Hilar | | | 3. Prevascular or retrotracheal | 6. Para aortic | 8. Para esophageal | 11. Interlobar | | | 4. Lower paratracheal | | 9. Pulmonary ligament | 12. Lobar | | | | | | 13. Segmental | | | | | | 14. Sub segmental | *Handwritten notes:* Eight Esoph ✓HILSS → HILSS **N1:** *Ipsilateral peribronchial* and/or *ipsilateral hilar lymph nodes* and *intrapulmonary nodes*. **N2:** *Ipsilateral mediastinal* and/or *subcarinal lymph node(s)* **N3:** *Ipsilateral scalene* or *supraclavicular* or *contralateral mediastinal/ hilar/ scalene /supraclavicular lymph node(s)* --- # Presence of metastasis is stage IV **M1a** tumor with pleural or pericardial nodules or malignant pleural or pericardial effusion. Separate tumor nodule(s) in another lung; **M1b**: Single extra thoracic metastasis in a single organ **M1c**: Multiple extra thoracic metastases in a single organ or in multiple organs --- T1a T1b T1c ✓ | Stage | T | N | M | | :--------- | :-------- | :-------- | :-- | | (STAGE IA) | Any T1 | (N0) | M0 ✓ | | STAGE IB | (T2a) | N0 | M0 ✗ | | STAGE IIA | (T2b) | N0 ✓ | M0 | | STAGE IIB | _T1/T2_ | (N1) | M0 | | | (T3) | N0 | M0 | | STAGE IIIA | _T1/T2_ | N2 ✓ | M0 | | | (T3) | (N1) | M0 | | | T4 | _N0/N1_ | M0 | | STAGE IIIB | T1/T2 | ==N3== | M0 | | | _T3/T4_ | _N2_ | M0 | | STAGE IIIC | T3/T4 | ==N3== | M0 | | STAGE IV | Any T | Any N | M1 | **Handwritten Notes:** Stage III Mo [Stage IV M1] { un resectable (referring to STAGE IIIB and STAGE IIIC) --- Dr. Bharath Matha --- Management of NSCLC Dr. M. Ravikrishna MD DM CONSULTANT MEDICAL & HEMATO ONCOLOGIST ( TMH mumbai ) KIMS SUNSHINE , BEGUMPET HYDERABAD ---

# Multidisciplinary tumour board +++ **Patient** The patient is at the center of the multidisciplinary tumour board, with input from various specialties: * **Pulmonology** * Bronchoscopic spread? * EBUS / EUS? * Pulmonary function? * **Surgery** * Feasibility of R0 resection? * LN single vs. multiple? * Lobec/pneumonectomy? * **Radiation** * Radiation field? * Previous RT? * Presence ILD? * **Oncology** * Performance status? * Organ functions? * Patient preference? * **Pathology** * Tumor type? * PD-L1 expression? * **Imaging** * Overall spread? GUSTAVE ROUSSY ESMO ESMO ACADEMY VIRTUAL MEETING --- # Locoregional staging according to 8th edition of TNM ESMO Metastasis * **N0** * **N1:** Ipsilateral peribronchial and/or hilar lymph nodes and intrapulmonary nodes * **N2:** Ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal lymph nodes * **N3:** Metastasis in contralateral mediastinal, hilar, ipsilateral or contralateral scalene, or supraclavicular lymph nodes Brierley JD et al (eds). TNM Classification of Malignant Tumours, 8th edition. John Wiley & Sons, Inc., Oxford, 2016 --- # For diagnosis and staging ## Imaging The impact of PET on staging has shown, an up-stage in 16–41%, and down-stage in 6–20% of patients [10,12,13]. Two multi-centric trials have shown that the use of PET could reduce unnecessary thoracotomies in up to 20% of patients with suspected or proven NSCLC [14,15]. ## Tissue | Parameter | Mandatory | Optional | |---|---|---| | General | Medical history\*
Physical examination\*
Assessing comorbidity | | | Cardio-pulmonary function | FVC, FEV1, DLCO
ECG
If indicated, CPET | Ejection fraction, CAG | | Tissue procurement | Bronchoscopy^§
EBUS/EUS mediastinal nodes\*
CT-guided biopsy ! | Mediastinoscopy | --- **Additional Notes/Footnotes (partially visible):** * pathological * recommended prior to * treatment * confirmation of * lymph nodes EBUS * EUS does not reveal nodal involvement in a situation of high clinical suspicion, mediastinoscopy indicated --- Known or suspected NSCLC * **Contrast-Enhanced Chest CT (+liver & adrenal)** * **Negative / borderline positive Chest CT, clinical stage I/II** * **FDG PET-CT** * PET-CT(-) and peripheral cl * No further mediastinal work-up * PET-CT(-) * VATS or EBUS/EUS-NA * PET-CT(+) * Tissue confirmation required * Context-based strategy * **Massive N2/N3 disease on Chest CT** * No further mediastinal work-up * PET CT for metastatic workup * Context based strategy Molecular testing – EGFR, ALK PDL1 in stage 1-3, NGS testing in stage 4, MRI brain in all stages except stage IA, IB (optional) --- ```markdown CT and PETCT OR PETCT ↓ Mediastinal nodes Negative ↓ cNO and peripheral tumor ( outer 1/3rd ) Tsize - < 3 cms ↓ SURGERY ``` --- * **Initial Imaging:** CT and PETCT OR PETCT * **Result:** Mediastinal nodes Negative * **Further Evaluation (if Mediastinal nodes Negative and specific conditions met):** * **Conditions:** N1 Or central tumor or Tsize > 4 cms * **Procedure:** Tissue confirmation (EBUS / EUS Or VAM) * **Outcome of Tissue Confirmation:** * If Mediastinal nodes POSITIVE: * **Treatment:** MULTIMODALITY TREATMNET * If Mediastinal nodes Negative: * **Treatment:** SURGERY --- CT and PETCT OR PETCT * Mediastinal nodes Negative * cNO and peripheral tumor (outer 1/3rd) Tsize - < 3 cms * SURGERY * N1 Or central tumor Tsize > 4 cms * Tissue confirmation EBUS / EUS Or VAM * Mediastinal nodes POSITIVE * MULTIMODALITY TREATMNET * Mediastinal nodes Negative * SURGERY --- - CT and PETCT OR PETCT - Mediastinal nodes Positive N2 - Tissue confirmation EBUS / EUS - Mediastinal nodes POSITIVE - MULTIMODALITY TREATMNET - SURGERY - Mediastinal nodes NEGATIVE - VAM - Mediastinal nodes POSITIVE - Mediastinal nodes NEGATIVE - SURGERY --- CT and PETCT OR PETCT * Mediastinal nodes Negative * cNO and peripheral tumor ( outer 1/3rd ) Tsize - < 3 cms * SURGERY * N1 Or central tumor Tsize > 4 cms * Tissue confirmation EBUS / EUS Or VAM * Mediastinal nodes Negative * SURGERY * Mediastinal nodes POSITIVE * MULTIMODALITY TREATMNET * Mediastinal nodes Positive N2 * Tissue confirmation EBUS / EUS * Mediastinal nodes POSITIVE * MULTIMODALITY TREATMNET * Mediastinal nodes NEGATIVE * VAM * Mediastinal nodes POSITIVE * MULTIMODALITY TREATMNET * Mediastinal nodes NEGATIVE * SURGERY --- # Lung Cancer : Classification The image displays a classification of lung cancer stages using a horizontal bar: * **Stage I-II** (grey segment) * **Stage III** (blue segment) * **Stage IV** (red segment) Stage 1&2 : T1-2 N0 , T3 N0, T1-2 N1 Primary modality is surgery --- # What do the guidelines say? **Stage IB-IIIA** * **R0 resection [I, A]** * Adjuvant ChT in N+ [I, A]* * Adjuvant ChT in resected tumours ≥ 4 cm (T2bN0, stage IIA) [II, B] * **R1 resection** * PORT [IV, B] * Adjuvant ChT [V, A] **Chemotherapy Regimens:** * Cisplatin [I, A] in combination with: * Vinorelbine [I, A] * Gemcitabine [II, B] * Docetaxel [II, B] * Pemetrexed [II, B, non-squamous] * If cisplatin is not feasible, carboplatin is an alternative [IV, B] * If resected primary tumour ≥ 4 cm and N0, carboplatin-paclitaxel [IV, B] # LACE Meta-analysis – 5+ year follow up N=2380 patients in 5 randomized trials * +5.3% survival at 5 years * HR OS: 0.89 (0.82-0.96); P=0.005 * HR PFS: 0.84 (0.78-0.91); P<0.001 | STAGE | Count 1 | Count 2 | Forest Plot Data | | :------- | :------ | :------ | :--------------- | | Stage IA | 104 | 347 | 0.06, 0.04* | | Stage IB | 515 | 1,371 | | | Stage II | 893 | 1,616 | | | Stage III| 878 | 1,247 | | --- Adjuvant cisplatin-based chemotherapy standard in resected stage II, III NSCLC (only 59% of eligible patients in Canada receive adjuvant chemotherapy) LACE meta-analysis: vinorelbine/cisplatin | Category | OS | | DFS | | | :------- | :------------------------------- | :---------------------------- | :-------------------------------- | :---------------------------- | | | **No. Deaths / No. Entered** | **Hazard Ratio [95% CI]** | **No. Events / No. Entered** | **Hazard Ratio [95% CI]** | | Stage I | 238/679 | 1.01 [0.76, 1.30] | 298/679 | 0.95 [0.76, 1.19] | | Stage II | 371/721 | 0.74 [0.60, 0.91] | 424/721 | 0.69 [0.57, 0.83] | | Stage III| 326/488 | 0.66 [0.53, 0.83] | 355/488 | 0.62 [0.50, 0.76] | | | **Chemotherapy effect: p < 0.001** | | **Chemotherapy effect: p < 0.001** | | | | Test for heterogeneity: $\chi^2$ 14.46 p = 0.16 $I^2$ = 31 % | Test for heterogeneity: $\chi^2$ 15.13 p = 0.13 $I^2$ = 34 % | | | Test for interaction: p = 0.04 | Test for trend: p = 0.02 | Test for interaction: p = 0.02 | Test for trend: p = 0.008 | **Survival (%) over Time from Randomization (Years)** Legend: * ... Cisplatin-vinorelbine * ... No chemotherapy | Stage | Group | 1 Year | 2 Years | 3 Years | 4 Years | 5 Years | $\ge$ 6 Years | | :------- | :-------------------- | :----- | :------ | :------ | :------ | :------ | :------------ | | **Stage I** | Cisplatin-vinorelbine | | | 74.3 | 68.7 | 64.7 | 59.9 | | | No chemotherapy | | | 73.1 | 66.7 | 59.9 | 54.9 | | **Stage II**| Cisplatin-vinorelbine | | | 56.2 | 54.4 | 49.9 | 42.8 | | | No chemotherapy | | | 48.2 | 42.8 | 39.9 | 38.7 | | **Stage III**| Cisplatin-vinorelbine | | | 38.7 | 33.9 | 29.3 | 25.3 | | | No chemotherapy | | | 25.3 | 20.9 | 18.9 | 15.3 | Pignon JP et al J Thorac Oncol 2010; Kris et al J Clin Oncol 2017; Crino et al Ann Oncol 2010; NCCN; CPAC Lung Cancer System Report 2011 --- # Newer cisplatin doublets have similar outcomes In non-squamous NSCLC, pemetrexed/cisplatin less toxic than vinorelbine/cisplatin **ECOG1505 (+/- bevacizumab)** N=1501, resected IB >=4cm-IIIA 7th edition **JIPANG (nonsquamous)** N= 804, resected II-IIIA 7th edition ## Overall Survival Probability (ECOG1505) ### NonSquam, All Pts regardless of +/- Bev | Treatment | Events | Cases | | :-------- | :----- | :---- | | Cis/Doce | 101 | 202 | | Cis/Gem | 61 | 134 | | Cis/Pem | 186 | 494 | | Cis/Vin | 104 | 248 |

sectionTitle: Squam, All Pts regardless of +/- Bev
content:
### Squam, All Pts regardless of +/- Bev

| Treatment | Events | Cases |
| :-------- | :----- | :---- |
| Cis/Doce  | 61     | 143   |
| Cis/Gem   | 62     | 151   |
| Cis/Vin   | 50     | 128   |



## Overall Survival (%) (JIPANG)

*   Vinorelbine plus cisplatin
*   Pemetrexed plus cisplatin
*   HR, 0.98 (95% CI, 0.71 to 1.35)
*   P = .434 (1-sided)

Vinorelbine/cisplatin more toxic
Febrile neutropenia 11.6% v 0.3%

---
Wakelee...Leighi et al WCLC 2019; Wakelee, Leighl et al Lancet Oncol 2017; Kenmotsu et al J Clin Oncol 2020

---

<!-- Page 52 -->



# What is the evidence in T >=4 cm N0 resected NSCLC?



## CALGB 9633 – resected T2N0 7th edition
Adjuvant carboplatin/paclitaxel

![CALGB 9633 Survival Probability Graph](image_crop_4.png)

*   **Chemotherapy** (N = 99)
*   **Control** (N = 97)
*   HR = 0.69
*   90% CI: 0.48 to 0.99
*   P = .043
*   **Time (Months)**
*   **Survival Probability**

T<4 cm OS HR: 1.12 p NS



## NCIC CTG JBR.10 – subgroup analysis
Adjuvant cisplatin/vinorelbine (N=120)



### Stage 1B and Tumor Diameter ≥ 4 cm
![NCIC CTG JBR.10 Survival Probability Graph](image_crop_5.png)

*   **Observation**
*   **Chemotherapy**
*   Log rank: P = .133
*   HR 0.66 (95% CI, 0.39 to 1.14)
*   **Time (years)**

T<4 cm OS HR: 1.73 p=0.056



## Size remains key predictor



### JBR.10 Exploratory Analysis of Pathologic Factors in T2N0 (n=217)

| Factor                                                              | HR [95% CI]      | p-value |
| :------------------------------------------------------------------ | :--------------- | :------ |
| Tumor Size ≥4cm\*                                                   | 2.4 [1.2-4.8]    | p=0.008 |
| High LDH                                                            | 3.1 [1.6-6.3]    | p=0.001 |
| Moderate Inflammation                                               | 2.3 [1.1-4.8]    | p=0.02  |
| Moderate Fibrosis                                                   | 2.7 [1.3-5.8]    | p=0.007 |
| Lymphatic Invasion\*                                                | 0.46 [0.25-1.2]  | p=0.11  |
| Vascular Invasion                                                   | 0.39 [0.1-1.4]   | p=0.15  |
| *Note: Visceral Pleural Involvement Neither Prognostic nor Predictive of Benefit* |                  |         |

---
Strauss et al J Clin Oncol 2008, Butts et al J Clin Oncol 2009, Strevel et al ASCO 2007

---

<!-- Page 53 -->

Shift to 8th edition: >4cm tumors now stage II – easy!!

| TNM 7<sup>th</sup> EDITION | TNM 8<sup>th</sup> EDITION |
| :---------------------- | :-------------------- |
| **T**                   |                       |
|                         | Tis                   |
|                         | Tmi                   |
|                         | Tss                   |
| T1a (≤2 cm)             | T1a (≤1 cm)           |
| T1b (>2-3 cm)           | T1b (>1-2cm)          |
|                         | T1c (>2-3cm)          |
| T2a (>3-5 cm)           | T2a (>3cm but ≤4cm)   |
| T2b (>5-7 cm)           | T2b (>4cm but ≤5cm)   |
| T3 (>7 cm)              | T4                    |
| T3 - atelectasis/pneumonitis involving whole lung) | T2 atelectasis/pneumonitis irrespective of involving lobe or whole lung |
| T3 tumor involving the main bronchus <2cm distance to carina | T2 -tumor involving the main bronchus irrespective of distance to carina |
| T3 -invasion of the diaphragm | T4 (invasion of the diaphragm) |
| **N** No changes        |                       |
| **M** M1b - distant metastasis | M1b - single extrathoracic metastasis |
|                         | M1c - multiple extrathoracic metastases |

|       | N0    | N1    | N2    | N3    |
| :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- |
| **T1**  | IA    | IIB   | IIIA  | IIIB  |
| **T2a** | IB    | IIB   | IIIA  | IIIB  |
| **T2b** | IIA   | IIB   | IIIA  | IIIB  |
| **T3**  | IIB   | IIIA  | IIIB  | IIIC  |
| **T4**  | IIIA  | IIIA  | IIIB  | IIIC  |
| **M1a** | IVA   | IVA   | IVA   | IVA   |
| **M1b** | IVA   | IVA   | IVA   | IVA   |
| **M1c** | IVB   | IVB   | IVB   | IVB   |

<!-- Page 55 -->



# Adjuvant Chemotherapy in Early Non-small cell Lung Cancer



## Indications for Adjuvant chemotherapy-

*   Stage IIA to IIIA i.e., any tumor more than 4cm and/or N1 or N2 node positive as per current 8th AJCC TNM
*   Stage I lung cancer with a tumor size 4cm (stage IB), poorly differentiated histology, vascular or lymphatic invasion, visceral pleura invasion may be considered for adjuvant chemotherapy.
*   Other factors to consider for those eligible for adjuvant chemotherapy includes timing within 4 – 6 weeks of surgery, performance status ECOG 0 or 1, comorbidity.

---

<!-- Page 56 -->



# Which regimen to choose?


## Adjuvant Chemotherapy Regimens

*   For non-squamous NSCLC the preferred regimen is cisplatin +pemetrexed based combination
*   For the squamous variant, cisplatin with gemcitabine or docetaxel is preferred, other recommended options include cisplatin +vinorelbine, cisplatin +etoposide.

For patients with comorbidities making them cisplatin ineligible, carboplatin may be used instead of cisplatin.

---

<!-- Page 57 -->

What is the option for those who are EGFR mutation positive?

**Adjuvant Osimertinib** should be considered for duration of **36 months** in resected non-squamous NSCLC Stage II to III (AJCC 8th edition) carrying sensitizing EGFR (Exon 19 del or Exon 21 L858R) irrespective of feasibility of adjuvant platinum-based chemotherapy.

Based on this it is now standard practice to test these patients for EGFR mutation.

Similarly, at present though there is no recommendation for adjuvant ALK directed therapy, but studies are ongoing and soon may change our current approach for these patients too.

---

<!-- Page 58 -->

What is new?

ImpoweR010, has shown remarkable disease-free survival advantage with **Atezolizumab for 1 year after adjuvant chemotherapy** as consolidation over best supportive care in **stage II to IIIA completely resected patients with PDL1 more than 1%**.

This is now approved by FDA, NCCN and EMA for eligible patients based on this study

---

<!-- Page 59 -->

Lung Cancer : Classification

Stage I-II | Stage III | Stage IV

Stage III : T3 N1-N3 -T4 N0-3

---

<!-- Page 60 -->

A Case...
* 60 year old male, ex-smoker (20 pack years, quit 23 years ago), retired teacher, well (controlled BP, cholesterol)
* Referred to thoracic surgery based on "routine" CT
* 6 mm LUL semisolid nodule in periphery of rt lung lower lobe – followed for 3 months --> minor growth
* Biopsy: adenocarcinoma
* Preoperative PET: no avid disease
* Underwent VATS lobectomy (ctDNA detected preop in "ctDNA Detect" clinical trial)

Pathology: LUL 1.2 cm adenocarcinoma, LVI+, station 4R+ TP53 mutation, PD-L1<1%: T1bN2 or IIIA NSCLC

BP: blood pressure, LUL: left upper lobe; PET: positron emission tomography; VATS: video assisted thoracoscopy; LVI: lymphovascular invasion; PD-L1: programmed death ligand-1

---

<!-- Page 61 -->



# Incidental' N2 disease

When the SMLND yields positive N2 nodes, despite an adequate pre-operative invasive mediastinal staging; the patient should receive adjuvant chemotherapy after a meticulous R0 resection.

- The reason for this could be micro metastases, involvement of inferior pulmonary ligament or aortapulmonary ligament nodes which cannot be sampled by routine techniques or a false negative invasive staging.

ADJUVANT chemo with 4# 3 weekly once pemetrexed + cisplatin or gemcitabine + cisplatin

---

<!-- Page 62 -->

Resectable- Locally advanced
IIIA
N2 -not bulky

---

<!-- Page 63 -->

Single station, resectable N2 disease

Surgery remains an integral part of the multimodality treatment algorithm.

This disease mandates chemotherapy, either neoadjuvant or adjuvant. Most of the available evidence favours neo-adjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery. Neo-adjuvant chemoradiation has also been instituted with good results in some centers.

Some centers prescribe a restaging mediastinoscopy post neo-adjuvant therapy for N2 disease; a persistent positive N2 precluding surgical resection. However, the nay-sayers to this approach maintain that in disease that has not responded to chemotherapy +/-radiation, surgery remains the only curative treatment option.

Neo -ADJUVANT chemo with 4# 3 weekly once pemetrexed + cisplatin or gemcitabine + cisplatin f/b surgery

---

<!-- Page 64 -->



# UNRESECTABLE

**N3 disease -**
*   Involvement of contralateral mediastinal nodes or supraclavicular nodes
*   Consensus is for treatment with **definitive chemoradiation** with adjuvant **Durvalumab** where feasible

**Multistation, bulky N2 disease -**
*   Multiple ipsilateral mediastinal stations involved with large, 'bulky' nodes
*   Best treated with **definitive chemoradiation followed by Durvalumab**

**Unresectable N2 disease -**
*   The definition of 'unresectable' is not standardized.
*   Most centers consider mediastinal nodes > 3 cm in diameter as bulky or unresectable.
*   The recommendation for this disease is treatment with **definitive chemoradiation followed by Durvalumab.**

**Definitive CTRT f/b durvalumab (10 mg/kg intravenously; administered once every 2 weeks for 12 months)**

---

<!-- Page 65 -->

N2 disease
*   **If Single station, Resectable:**
    *   Neo-adjuvant Chemotherapy chemoradiation
    *   Surgery
*   **If Single station, unresectable:**
    *   Definitive Chemoradiation & Durvalumab
    *   Residual Disease
    *   Surgery
*   **If Multistation:**
    *   Definitive Chemoradiation & Durvalumab
    *   Residual Disease
    *   Surgery
*   **If Incidental:**
    *   Adjuvant Chemotherapy

---

<!-- Page 66 -->

# Locally Advanced Primary Tumour



## Chest wall/ Pericardial invasion - Included in T3 tumours. -

*   -Surgery is feasible and safe, if a complete (R0) resection can be ensured.
*   -Shallow invasion (parietal pleura) may be dealt with by extrapleural dissection while deeper invasion warrants en bloc resection of soft tissue and ribs.
*   -En bloc resections have a higher morbidity and mortality compared to standard lobectomy.
*   -Long-term survival in completely resected patients ranges from 36-67% in those with T3N0 while survival drops to <10% in N2 disease, emphasizing diligent staging and patient selection.

---

<!-- Page 67 -->

**Diaphragm invasion:** -
*   Included in T4 tumours
*   En bloc resection of the diaphragm is safe and offers chance of cure in selected patients.
*   Completely resected cases with diaphragmatic invasion have a long-term survival ranging from 20-43% in T4N0 stages.
*   There is no established role for neo-adjuvant or adjuvant treatment on account of chest wall, pericardial or diaphragmatic invasion alone.
*   Neo-adjuvant treatment depends on the N2 nodal status.
*   Adjuvant treatment is dictated by the tumour size and nodal status.

---

<!-- Page 68 -->

Diaphragm invasion: -
Included in T4 tumours

En bloc resection of the diaphragm is safe and offers chance of cure in selected patients.

Completely resected cases with diaphragmatic invasion have a long-term survival ranging from 20-43% in T4N0 stages.

There is no established role for neo-adjuvant or adjuvant treatment on account of chest wall, pericardial or diaphragmatic invasion alone.

Neo-adjuvant treatment depends on the N2 nodal status.

Adjuvant treatment is dictated by the tumour size and nodal status.

---

<!-- Page 69 -->



# Superior sulcus/ Pancoast tumour: -

-Include tumours infiltrating the posterior part of apical pleuropulmonary groove and involving structures of the thoracic inlet such as subclavian vessels, brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, etc.

induction chemoradiation followed by surgery.

Surgery is usually undertaken 3-5 weeks after induction therapy.

It entails en bloc resection of involved structures by a posterior or anterior approach.

Surgery is contraindicated in extensive involvement of brachial plexus, intraspinal extension, soft tissues of the neck and N2/N3 disease.

---

<!-- Page 70 -->



# CHEMOTHERAPY indications



## ADJUVANT
*   Stage IB - poorly differentiated histology, vascular or lymphatic invasion, visceral pleura invasion
*   Stage IIA to IIIA



## Scenarios in which NACT may be considered
*   In potentially resectable disease especially those with single-station mediastinal nodal involvement,
*   Superior sulcus tumors
*   Chest wall invasion in the setting of N1 nodal involvement

---

<!-- Page 71 -->



# Radiotherapy in Locally Advanced Lung Cancer Indications:



## DEFINITIVE CTRT
- Unresectable lung primary - N2 (Bulky, single station / Multistation) and N3 disease
- Patients not fit/ willing for surgery



## ADJUVANT
- As adjuvant for node positive disease (persistent N2/multiple node positive/ with ENE) or positive margins



## NEOADJUVANT
- As neoadjuvant chemoradiation followed by resection in superior sulcus tumor

# WORK FLOW

Stage 4 lung carcinoma

Check biopsy report
Squamous cell carcinoma or adeno ca

If squamous cell carcinoma –
*   IHC for PDL1
*   RTPCR FOR EGFR
*   NGS – 12 gene / 52 gene / CGP ( based on affordability )

If adeno ca --
*   IHC for ALK , ROS , PDL1
*   RT PCR FOR EGFR
*   NGS – 12 gene / 52 gene / CGP ( based on affordability )

If asyymptomatic -
*   Wait for NGS or molecular reports and then start therapy based on report

If symptomatic –
*   start chemo ( pemetrexed + carboplatin for adenoca ) , gemcitabine + carboplatin ( squamous cell ca )

Trace molecular reports before cycle 2 and modify therapy based on reports

# TARGETABLE BIOMARKERS IN NSCLC

**Oncogenic addiction**

*   NTRK
*   ALK
*   RET
*   EGFR:
    *   Ins exon 20
    *   S768L, G719X, L861Q
    *   del 19/L858R
*   HER2 ins exon 20
*   ROS

*   Met Exon 14
*   BRAF V600

**Onco-immunogenicity**

*   KRAS

Tumor heterogeneity, a gradient from oncogenic addiction to immunogenicity

<!-- Page 77 -->



# Incidence of $\text{EGFR}$ Mutations in Indian Lung Cancer -- a Study of 907 Patients

We studied incidence of known $\text{EGFR}$ mutations in 907 lung cancer patients using Sanger sequencing and TaqMan based real time PCR.

**Summary of $\text{EGFR}$ Mutation Incidence:**

*   **Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)**
    *   Total patients: n=907
    *   $\text{EGFR}$ mutant: 23%
    *   $\text{EGFR}$ wild-type: 77%

*   **Other NSCLC Subtypes**
    *   Others: n=24
    *   Squamous: n=103
        *   $\text{EGFR}$ mutant: 3.8%

*   **Adenocarcinoma**
    *   Total patients: n=780
    *   $\text{EGFR}$ mutant: 26%
    *   $\text{EGFR}$ wild-type: 74%

*   **Adenocarcinoma by Sex (n=780 cohort)**
    *   Female Adenocarcinoma: n=249
        *   $\text{EGFR}$ mutant: 32%
        *   $\text{EGFR}$ wild-type: 68%
    *   Male Adenocarcinoma: n=531
        *   $\text{EGFR}$ mutant: 23%
        *   $\text{EGFR}$ wild-type: 77%

*   **Adenocarcinoma by Sex (n=477 cohort)**
    *   Female Adenocarcinoma: n=244
        *   $\text{EGFR}$ mutant: 17%
        *   $\text{EGFR}$ wild-type: 83%
    *   Male Adenocarcinoma: n=233
        *   $\text{EGFR}$ mutant: 30%
        *   $\text{EGFR}$ wild-type: 70%

23% incidence of $\text{EGFR}$ mutation was observed in NSCLC patients of Indian ethnicity, in contrast to 10-15% known in Caucasians.

Chougule A. et al., PLOS One 2013

---

<!-- Page 78 -->

Testing for EGFR mutation - Methods used for diagnosis of EGFR mutation are
* quantitative Polymerase Chain reaction (qPCR),
* Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) and Sanger sequencing. -
* EGFR expression by immunohistochemistry (IHC) is not a recommended method for diagnosis of EGFR mutation.

EGFR copy number analysis (i.e by FISH/CISH) should not be used to select patients for targeted TKI therapy.

- As far as use of cell-free DNA (cf DNA) is concerned, there is insufficient evidence for its use for diagnosis. In situations when the tissue is limited or insufficient it may be used to identify EGFR mutation.

cf DNA can be used for diagnosis of secondary mutations of T790M on progression.

---

# EGFR Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors

Osimertinib is superior to 1st generation TKIs and has CNS activity, hence it is considered as a preferred option in first line treatment for NSCLC with sensitizing EGFR mutation. However, its cost is a major hindrance for its universal usage.

| EGFR TKI | Type of | Indication |
|---|---|---|
| Erlotinib | | |
| **Second generation TKI** | Irreversible | First line therapy |
| Afatinib | | |
| Dacomitinib | | |
| **Third generation TKI** | Irreversible | First line therapy |
| Osimertinib | | Second line therapy for T790M mutation |

---

<!-- Page 81 -->



## Options for first-line treatment of EGFR mutant advanced NSCLC -

*   1) Osimertinib- preferred choice due to its efficacy (superior PFS, OS), CNS activity, safety and tolerability.
*   2) Gefitinib + Chemotherapy- first line option in fit patients, especially in LMICs where most patients do not have access to Osimertinib
*   3) Dacomitinib
*   4) Gefitinib, Erlotinib- 1 st generation TKIs alone may be considered in patients who are elderly, por performance status>2
*   5) Afatinib-preferred in certain rare mutations based on data from pooled analysis of Lux Lung 3 & 6 trials
*   6) Erlotinib + Bevacizumab

---

# ALK Mutation- Incidence

Original Article
*ALK gene rearranged lung adenocarcinomas: molecular genetics and morphology in cohort of patients from North India*
Amanjit Bal, Navneet Singh, Parimal Agarwal, Ashim Das, Digambar Behera
First published: 08 August 2016 | https://doi.org/10.1111/apm.12581 | Citations: 6

*ALK* gene rearrangement in the lung adenocarcinomas is the second most common (1.6–11.7% of NSCLC) targetable genomic change after *EGFR* mutations¹.

**Mutation Incidence (from pie chart):**
*   No oncogenic driver identified: 38%
*   KRAS: 25%
*   EGFR: 23%
*   ALK: 7.8%
*   ERBB2: 2.7%
*   BRAF: 2.0%
*   PIK3CA: 0.8%
*   NRAS: 0.7%
*   MET: 0.7%
*   MEK1: 0.3%

Adapted from Journal of Thoracic Oncology, 2015

---
¹ Bal A, Singh N, Agarwal P, Das A, Behera D. APMIS. 2016 Oct;124(10):832-8.

<!-- Page 83 -->



# ALK Rearrangements in Lung Cancer

Approximately 5% of all NSCLC cases$^1$
*   Typically, adenocarcinoma histology.
*   Typically (but not always) never smokers or light former smokers.
*   Tend to occur in younger patient
*   Diagnostic techniques available
*   EML4-ALK and EGFR mutations are mutually exclusive

Different variants of EML4-ALK and non-EML4 fusion partners$^3$

| Fusion Type | Fusion Partner | ALK | Coiled-coil domain | Tyrosine kinase domain |
| :---------- | :------------- | :-- | :---------------- | :------------------ |
| EML4-ALK    |                |     |                   |                     |
| E13;A20     | EML4           | ALK |                   |                     |
| E6;A20      | EML4           | ALK |                   |                     |
| E20;A20     | EML4           | ALK |                   |                     |
| E14;A20     | EML4           | ALK |                   |                     |
| E18;A20     | EML4           | ALK |                   |                     |
| E15;A20     | EML4           | ALK |                   |                     |
| E2;A20      | EML4           | ALK |                   |                     |
| E17;A20     | EML4           | ALK |                   |                     |
| TFG-ALK     | TFG            | ALK |                   |                     |
| KIF5B-ALK   | KIF5B          | ALK |                   |                     |

**Legend:**
*   Coiled-coil domain
*   Tyrosine kinase domain

Adapted from Journal of Thoracic Oncology, 2015

Adapted from Sasaki T et al. Eur J Cancer 2010

Please see summary of prescribing information on last slide

1.  Sasaki T et al. Eur J Cancer. 2010 July; 46(10): 1773–1780.

---

<!-- Page 84 -->



# Testing for ALK Fusions -

**Break-apart fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH)** was established as the gold standard test to identify ALK gene rearrangement.

- The close association between a positive FISH test and modestly elevated ALK protein in tumor cells allows ALK immunohistochemistry (IHC) to be used routinely for testing.
- In the present algorithm for ALK testing, **IHC with Ventana D5F3 antibody is used as the first test**, in cases of **1+ or 2+ scoring, FISH is used as a confirmatory test**. Strong granular cytoplasmic staining in any percentage of positive tumor cells is regarded as **3+ and is a candidate for ALK inhibitor**.
- With increasing use of Next Generation sequencing (NGS), if the turnaround time is optimal (preferably up to two weeks), RNA-based NGS is an ideal test to be conducted at baseline in all patients of NSCLC.

---

<!-- Page 85 -->

ALK REARRANGEMENT POSITIVEᵐᵐ

ALK rearrangement positive
*   ALK rearrangement discovered prior to first-line systemic therapy
    *   FIRST-LINE THERAPYᵖᵖ
        *   **Preferred**
            *   Alectinibᵠᵠ (category 1)
            *   or
            *   Brigatinibᵠᵠ (category 1)
            *   or
            *   Lorlatinibᵠᵠ (category 1)
        *   **Other Recommended**
            *   Ceritinibᵠᵠ (category 1)
        *   **Useful In Certain Circumstances**
            *   Crizotinibᵠᵠ (category 1)
    *   Progression -> Subsequent Therapy (NSCL-27)
    *   Progression -> Subsequent Therapy (NSCL-28)
*   ALK rearrangement discovered during first-line systemic therapy
    *   Complete planned systemic therapy, including maintenance therapy, or interrupt, followed by alectinib (preferred) or brigatinib (preferred) or lorlatinib (preferred) or ceritinib
    *   Progression -> Subsequent Therapy (NSCL-27)
    *   or
    *   crizotinib
    *   Progression -> Subsequent Therapy (NSCL-28)

Stage IV lung carcinoma with BRAF V600 mutation
*   Dabrafenib/trametinib [III, A; MCBS 2]\*
    *   or
*   Platinum-based ChT [IV, A]

**Disease progression**

*   **Oligoprogression**
    *   Local treatment
    *   → Systemic progression
*   **Systemic progression**
    *   Dabrafenib/trametinib [III, A; MCBS 2]\*
        *   or
    *   Platinum-based ChT [IV, A] (see Figure 2) if BRAF/MEK inhibitors received in first line
    *   Consider immunochemotherapy as per Figure 2 if smoker [IV, B]

# 2024 IMMUNOTHERAPY TREATMENT OPTIONS


## ADVANCED NSCLC

**Advanced NSCLC without driver alteration**

*   **PD-L1 >50%**
    *   ICI + chemotherapy
    *   ICI monotherapy
    *   ICI combo therapy (NIVO/Ipi)
*   **PD-L1 1-49%**
    *   ICI + chemotherapy
    *   ICI monotherapy
    *   ICI combo therapy (NIVO/Ipi)
*   **PD-L1 <1%**
    *   ICI + chemotherapy
    *   ICI combo therapy (NIVO/Ipi)

---



### ICI-chemotherapy options

**Non-squamous**
*   Carbo or Cis/Pemetrexed/Pembro
*   Carbo/Taxol/Bev/Atezo
*   Carbo/Nab-Paclitaxel/Atezo
*   NIVO/Ipi + 2 cycles of histology-based chemotherapy

**Squamous**
*   Carboplatin/Taxane/Pembro
*   NIVO/Ipi + 2 cycles of histology-based chemotherapy

DO NOT START IMMUNOTHERAPY Before checking for driver mutation on NGS even if the patient is positive for PDL1

IF THE PATIENT IS POSITIVE FOR PDL1 and driver mutation – give weightage to driver mutation and start targeted therapy +/- chemo rather than PDL1

Known or suspected NSCLC

Contrast-Enhanced Chest CT (+liver & adrenal)
*   Negative / borderline positive Chest CT, clinical stage I/II
    *   FDG PET-CT
        *   PET-CT(-) and peripheral cl
            *   No further mediastinal work-up
        *   PET-CT(-)
            *   VATS or EBUS/EUS-NA
        *   PET-CT(+)
            *   Tissue confirmation required
            *   Context-based strategy
*   Massive N2/N3 disease on Chest CT
    *   No further mediastinal work-up

CT and PETCT OR PETCT
*   **Mediastinal nodes Negative**
    *   cNO and peripheral tumor ( outer 1/3rd ) Tsize - < 3 cms
        *   SURGERY
    *   N1 Or central tumor Tsize > 4 cms
        *   Tissue confirmation EBUS / EUS Or VAM
            *   Mediastinal nodes Negative
                *   SURGERY
            *   Mediastinal nodes POSITIVE
                *   MULTIMODALITY TREATMNET
*   **Mediastinal nodes Positive**
    *   Tissue confirmation EBUS / EUS
        *   Mediastinal nodes POSITIVE
            *   MULTIMODALITY TREATMNET
        *   Mediastinal nodes NEGATIVE
            *   VAM
                *   Mediastinal nodes POSITIVE
                    *   MULTIMODALITY TREATMNET
                *   Mediastinal nodes NEGATIVE

<!-- Page 95 -->

N2 disease
*   **If Single station, Resectable:**
    *   Neo-adjuvant Chemotherapy chemoradiation
    *   Followed by Surgery
*   **If Single station, unresectable:**
    *   Definitive Chemoradiation & Durvalumab
    *   If Residual Disease, then Surgery
*   **If Multistation:**
    *   Definitive Chemoradiation & Durvalumab
    *   If Residual Disease, then Surgery
*   **If Incidental:**
    *   Adjuvant Chemotherapy

---

<!-- Page 96 -->

WORK FLOW

Stage 4 lung carcinoma

Check biopsy report
Squamous cell carcinoma or adeno ca

If squamous cell carcinoma –
*   IHC for PDL1
*   RTPCR FOR EGFR
*   NGS – 12 gene / 52 gene / CGP (based on affordability)

If adeno ca –
*   IHC for ALK, ROS, PDL1
*   RT PCR FOR EGFR
*   NGS – 12 gene / 52 gene / CGP (based on affordability)

If asymptomatic -
Wait for NGS or molecular reports and then start therapy based on report

If symptomatic – start chemo (pemetrexed + carboplatin for adenoca), gemcitabine + carboplatin (squamous cell ca)

Trace molecular reports before cycle 2 and modify therapy based on reports
